article.title: Mobile technology keeps seniors active and healthy
article.teaser: The EU-funded PreventIT project developed a smartphone application that empowers senior citizens to self-manage their own health and physical activity.

section.sectionBody:
Europe‚Äôs population is greying, with life expectancy for both women and men being longer than ever before. Unfortunately, not all of these extra years come in the guise of healthy years. This creates a challenging situation where more people will need more healthcare, which must be provided by fewer people.
To meet this challenge, society must shift the focus from treatment to prevention. This in turn requires the development of personalised technological solutions that promote active and healthy ageing ‚Äì which is exactly what the EU-funded PreventIT project has done.
‚ÄúThrough the PreventIT project, we developed a smartphone and smartwatch application that empowers people 61 to 70 years of age to self-manage their own health and physical activity,‚Äù says Jorunn Helbostad, project coordinator and professor at the http://www.preventit.eu/index.php/consortium-partners/ntnu/ (Norwegian University of Science and Technology) (NTNU), the project‚Äôs lead partner. ‚ÄúThis by no means is a traditional exercise app, but one that integrates short bouts of activity into everyday life.‚Äù
Leveraging the power of mobile health
Using the PreventIT app, called iPAS, senior citizens can test their functional fitness and get personalised advice on improving their balance, strength, and level of physical activity. The app leverages the sensors embedded in all smartphones and smartwatches, which allows it to monitor what the user does throughout the course of a day. Based on this, each user receives tailored feedback that takes into account their own goals and preferences. The app also encourages online, social interaction.
The system was tested in two pilot studies, along with a feasibility randomised control trial. The latter compared the feasibility and usability of the user-centred iPAS system against the same intervention delivered via a traditional pen-and-paper format and against physical activity based on https://www.who.int/dietphysicalactivity/factsheet_olderadults/en/ (World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines). The trial lasted six months and included 180 participants.
‚ÄúThe participants liked the PreventIT system and changed their exercise behaviour, and also continued to use it after the completion of the intervention period,‚Äù says Prof. Helbostad. ‚ÄúThis demonstrates the long-term benefits of using mobile health applications to encourage senior citizens to adapt a more active lifestyle.‚Äù
Further developments planned
According to Helbostad, the PreventIT proof-of-concept iPAS system is well-positioned to be developed into a stand-alone solution or as part of a full mobile health system. ‚ÄúOur solution has shed light on a part of the population that we know very little about,‚Äù Prof. Helbostad says. ‚ÄúWe are very motivated to further develop our concept and better support active, healthy ageing.‚Äù

article.keywords: PreventIT, mobile technology, senior citizens, healthcare, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, NTNU, mobile health, World Health Organization, WHO

article.title: A scalable solution for the factories of the future
article.teaser: A flexible, automated and scalable production system will allow manufacturers to quickly react to changing production demands.

section.sectionBody:
Most of today‚Äôs manufacturing lines are grossly under-optimised. That‚Äôs because most manufacturing machinery is fixed, meaning factories don‚Äôt have the flexibility to adapt the factory floor to meet specific demands. This method is not only inefficient, it is ill-suited to today‚Äôs trend towards on-demand and small-batch production.
What factories need are scalable solutions, which is exactly what the EU-funded https://www.scalable40.eu (ScalABLE4.0 project) intends to provide.
‚ÄúOur goal was to develop scalable automation solutions that could be easily adapted to current production needs,‚Äù says Germano Veiga, a researcher at https://www.inesctec.pt/en (INESC TEC) and ScalABLE4.0 project coordinator.

section.sectionTitle: The sweet spot of automation and flexibility
section.sectionBody:
Researchers set out to both develop and demonstrate an open scalable production system (OSPS). ‚ÄúAn OSPS is a framework that enables the optimisation and maintenance of production lines ‚Äòon the fly‚Äô,‚Äù explains Veiga. ‚ÄúIt does this through visualisation and virtualisation of the line itself.‚Äù
To accomplish this, researchers established use cases at the manufacturing sites of two of the project‚Äôs partners. The use case at the https://www.scalable40.eu/index.php/psa-usecase/ (PSA site) was installed with an over-automation system with limited flexibility to adapt to product changes, while the use case at the https://www.scalable40.eu/index.php/simoldes-usecase/ (Simoldes site) was fitted with an under-automated system. By approaching the challenge from polar opposites, researchers hoped they would be able to easily identify the ‚Äòsweet spot‚Äô in terms of automation and flexibility.
‚ÄúOur integrated, multidisciplinary approach, which is rather unique for this type of project, combined developments from the shop floor to top management decision-making,‚Äù adds Veiga. ‚ÄúThis allowed us to push the boundaries of advanced robotic systems, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_twin (digital twin) and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_integration (vertical integration), https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manufacturing_execution_system (manufacturing execution systems), and simulation and decision support.‚Äù
Out of this work came the blueprint for an integrated digital production system that is flexible, robotised and human-aware. ‚ÄúNow, when production needs change, manufacturers can immediately visualise how best to adapt the factory floor, robots and human labour and act accordingly,‚Äù notes Veiga. ‚ÄúThis all happens with minimal downtime, meaning increased efficiency and production.‚Äù

section.sectionTitle: Rewriting the production lines of the future
section.sectionBody:
Unfortunately, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the project was unable to finalise its test sprints at the two manufacturing sites or present at the https://automatica-munich.com/en/ (AUTOMATICA trade fair). ‚ÄúI think the response to this challenge and the implementation of contingency plans were handled brilliantly by the team,‚Äù says Veiga. ‚ÄúWe quickly adjusted to this new reality and were able to conduct full laboratory demonstrations of the ScalABLE4.0 solution.‚Äù
Despite these challenges, the project succeeded in showing that it is possible to integrate enterprise information systems, automation equipment and open https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/API (application programming interfaces) (APIs) to achieve system optimisation. ‚ÄúIn doing so, ScalABLE4.0 is helping to rewrite the standards for the production lines of the future,‚Äù concludes Veiga.
Several end users have already shown interest in industrialising the project‚Äôs main results. Furthermore, the project‚Äôs results led to the creation of the https://www.riact.eu/ (RiACT) spin-off.

article.keywords: ScalABLE4.0, open scalable production system, OSPS, factories, factory, production, digital production, scalable, manufacturing, automation, robotic systems

article.title: The new synergies of shopping: E-commerce or ‚Äòbricks and mortar‚Äô?
article.teaser: For many, a day of shopping is a favourite pastime, as so eloquently inferred by the fictional character we quote this month. Shopping perceived as a leisure activity really only came into being during the 1980s and 1990s, as free time and disposable incomes zipped upwards following a credit-flushed economic boom that defined the age. Consumer spending became an extremely important component to analyse when measuring an economy‚Äôs overall state and future prospects.

article.title: New tools to help organisations become cyber-aware
article.teaser: Following an increase in homeworking, organisations are more vulnerable to cyberattacks than ever before. A new cybersecurity training initiative aims to mitigate this risk through practical knowledge and hands-on practice.

section.sectionBody:
Too many companies make the mistake of seeing cybersecurity as an ‚ÄòIT problem‚Äô. But nothing could be further from the truth. ‚ÄúA phishing email sent to an employee and a click of a mouse is all it takes to give a hacker a direct path to an organisation‚Äôs network,‚Äù explains Rodrigo Diaz-Rodriguez, head of the https://atos.net/en/ (Atos) Cybersecurity Unit.
According to Diaz-Rodriguez, training is crucial to helping organisations become cyber-aware. ‚ÄúWith the COVID-19 pandemic bringing an increase in homeworking, companies are now particularly vulnerable to malicious cyberattacks,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAs such, the need for effective cybersecurity training is more pressing than ever.‚Äù
Meeting this need is the EU-funded CYBERWISER.EU project. ‚ÄúFrom teaching employees to strengthen their password to helping system administrators implement comprehensive protection strategies, CYBERWISER.EU helps organisations mitigate their risk of a cyberattack,‚Äù adds Diaz-Rodriguez.

The main aim of the project is to increase an organisation‚Äôs capacity to address advanced cyberthreats. ‚ÄúWe do this by providing tailored and efficient training that addresses the specific needs of professionals while also raising the organisation‚Äôs awareness about cybersecurity,‚Äù remarks Diaz-Rodriguez.
All 22 courses are delivered via the project‚Äôs user-friendly https://www.cyberwiser.eu/ (cyber range platform). The platform leverages state-of-the-art methodologies and tools and uses a combination of theory and practice to help an organisation develop a robust cyber response and decision-making processes. Courses are comprised of a variety of presentations, audio content, quizzes and hands-on exercises.
‚ÄúOne of the platform‚Äôs most popular features is the opportunity to use our cyberattack simulator,‚Äù explains Diaz-Rodriguez. ‚ÄúBy playing the role of ‚Äòdefender‚Äô or ‚Äòattacker‚Äô, participants get hands-on practice with responding to a cyberattack and a unique understanding of how they work.‚Äù
Diaz-Rodriguez adds that courses are available for all skill levels. ‚ÄúCYBERWISER.EU is completely flexible and customisable, meaning it can be tailored to meet your organisation‚Äôs unique needs ‚Äì and budget,‚Äù he notes.
‚ÄúWhether your staff have little to no knowledge of cybersecurity or you are an advanced IT team looking to enhance your cybersecurity capabilities, CYBERWISER.EU has a solution for you.‚Äù

During trial runs in the transport, academia and energy sectors, CYBERWISER.EU provided training to more than 500 individuals from over 20 institutions. Based on this success, the project team is currently preparing to make the training commercially available.
‚ÄúOur idea is to develop a modular offering that allows users to access training on specific skills and topics, including malware, spoofing, phishing scams, spam emails, SQL injection, and password cracking,‚Äù says Diaz-Rodriguez.
The project has received expressions of interest from 41 organisations, with 146 users already using a beta version of the commercial platform via a free trial offer.

article.keywords: CYBERWISER.EU, cyberattacks, cybersecurity, hacker, phishing, homeworking, cyberthreats, IT

article.title: Squaring the Arctic Circle: Protecting and preserving Earth‚Äôs Far North
article.teaser: Back in 2019, your editor was trying to catch a ride on a ship. This was no ordinary sea voyage: the Polarstern, a German research icebreaker, planned to sail to the Arctic, where it would tether itself to an ice floe. Then, as the sea froze around it, the ship and its passengers ‚Äì engineers, researchers and a scattering of journalists ‚Äì would be carried through the long Arctic winter with the drifting ice, eventually expelled into the Fram Strait come spring.

article.title: Early-predicted prognosis improves rheumatoid arthritis treatment outcomes
article.teaser: A new device that produces accurate patient prognosis helps rheumatologists improve the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

section.sectionBody:
https://www.rheumatology.org/I-Am-A/Patient-Caregiver/Diseases-Conditions/Rheumatoid-Arthritis (Rheumatoid arthritis) (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects not only the joints, but also the skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels.
The key to controlling the disease is identifying which patients need to promptly start intensive therapy. However, doing so requires an early diagnosis, which can be difficult as RA‚Äôs early symptoms are similar to other diseases. This is compounded by the fact that a prognostic test to refine, or personalise, RA‚Äôs current https://www.arthritis-health.com/blog/treat-target-new-approach-rheumatoid-arthritis-treatment (‚Äòtreat to target‚Äô) strategy does not exist. As a result, about 43 % of patients are misclassified for treatment intensity.
According to researchers with the EU-funded PAPRAT project, the solution is having an early prediction of a patient‚Äôs prognosis.
‚ÄúOur aim is to improve current rheumatology clinical practice at the earliest stages of rheumatoid arthritis,‚Äù says Lorena S√°nchez Mart√≠n, director of https://www.making-genetics.eu/en/ (Making Genetics), a Spanish medical diagnostic/prognostic technology company, and PAPRAT project coordinator.

At the core of the project is a multi-biomarker that only requires a routine blood sample from the RA clinical lab and some basic clinical data. By combining clinical and demographic factors, the device produces a highly accurate patient prognosis that healthcare providers can use to select the best therapy for managing the disease.
‚ÄúThe tool is able to identify those patients with a good prognosis and who will respond to first-line treatments, such as conventional https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease-modifying_antirheumatic_drug (DMARDs),‚Äù explains Mart√≠n. ‚ÄúMore importantly, it quickly identifies those with a poor prognosis and who will benefit from starting high-intensity therapies.‚Äù
The PAPRAT project oversaw phase 1 of the tool‚Äôs development. Work included validating the tool in a relevant environment of 443 patient samples from six different European hospitals and setting up clinical trials.
Project researchers also reviewed all regulatory requirements, a process that involved demonstrating the clinical performance, security and quality needed to achieve commercial approval.
One challenge the project had to overcome was a change in the governing regulatory framework for in vitro diagnostic medical devices. ‚ÄúBecause we had a comprehensive quality system, a thoroughly designed clinical study, and a careful post-market surveillance plan, we were able to quickly adapt to these more restrictive regulations,‚Äù adds Mart√≠n.
The project also helped enhance the tool‚Äôs technological components, along with performing a comprehensive market and financial analysis.

The project succeeded in proving the tool‚Äôs technical viability and ensuring it complied with all relevant regulations. As a result, it is now well-positioned for a successful market entry.
‚ÄúPAPRAT is the first prognosis tool specifically designed to classify RA patients attending their requirements of treatment intensity,‚Äù concludes Mart√≠n.
‚ÄúMost importantly, by giving rheumatologists an early start at effectively treating and managing RA, patients will benefit from an improved quality of life.‚Äù
Project researchers are currently applying for phase 2 funding, which they will use to further develop the tool‚Äôs technology.

article.keywords: PAPRAT, rheumatoid arthritis, rheumatologists, early diagnosis

article.title: From hair cells to hearing loss
article.teaser: New discoveries about how inner ear hair cells are formed could open the door to developing therapeutic approaches to treating hearing loss.

section.sectionBody:
What do embryos, hair cells and hearing have to do with one another? Turns out, a lot. ‚ÄúHumans develop hair cells in our inner ear as embryos,‚Äù says David Sprinzak, a researcher at https://english.tau.ac.il/ (Tel Aviv University).
As Sprinzak explains, these inner ear hair cells are highly specialised cells that are responsible for turning sound vibrations into electrical signals. These signals are then conveyed to the brain, which essentially translates them into the sounds we hear.
Unfortunately, as we grow older, we begin to lose these hair cells and, with it, some of our ability to hear properly. But this could soon change, thanks in part to the work being done by the EU-funded MorphoNotch project.
The project, which is being spearheaded by https://www.sprinzak.sites.tau.ac.il/ (Sprinzak‚Äôs Lab) and received support from the https://erc.europa.eu/ (European Research Council), is working to better understand the processes that cause hair cells to form during embryonic development. ‚ÄúIf we know how these hair cells are formed, we might be able to regenerate them as a means of treating, if not preventing, hearing loss,‚Äù explains Sprinzak.

At the heart of the project is the effort to understand how hair cells in the inner ear form a precise pattern of four rows during embryonic development. According to Sprinzak, this cellular pattern is important for the function of the inner ear.
‚ÄúWe wanted to understand how such an important and complex structure emerges during embryonic development,‚Äù he says.
To do so, the research team focused on Notch signalling, the primary pathway for coordinating the differentiation between neighbouring cells in animals. ‚ÄúIn particular, we looked at the interplay between Notch signalling and the mechanical forces that control the development of the mammalian inner ear,‚Äù adds Sprinzak.

section.sectionTitle: How cells organise during embryonic development
section.sectionBody:
What the project found is that Notch signalling controls the formation of an initially disordered pattern of hair cells. However, these cells eventually reorganise into an ordered pattern in a process that is analogous to the formation of a crystal, a process typically observed in atomic physics.
‚ÄúThis discovery represents a new developmental mechanism for how cells organise during embryonic development,‚Äù remarks Sprinzak.
But perhaps the project‚Äôs most important finding was that these two processes, the differentiation of hair cells controlled by Notch signalling and the reorganisation of cells controlled by mechanical forces, are intimately coupled. ‚ÄúI am very proud of this discovery because we were able to identify a fundamental process that has implications in the development of many other tissues and organs,‚Äù explains Sprinzak.

section.sectionTitle: New therapeutic approaches to treating hearing loss
section.sectionBody:
With this fundamental understanding of how hair cells are formed, Sprinzak is now turning his attention to studying regenerative approaches to hearing loss. ‚ÄúHair cell regeneration in the inner ear is an exciting field that focuses on developing methods to induce the regeneration of sensory hair cells,‚Äù he adds.
Sprinzak is confident that the concepts introduced during the MorphoNotch project will play a fundamental role in this field.
‚ÄúOur findings have the potential to contribute to the development of new therapeutic approaches to treating hearing loss,‚Äù he concludes.

article.keywords: MorphoNotch, hair cells, hearing loss, inner ear, embryonic development, Notch signalling
